introduction.description: The Grade 11 Physics curriculum introduces students to fundamental concepts in mechanics, heat and thermodynamics, waves and optics, and electricity and magnetism, fostering critical thinking and practical application skills for real-world scenarios like motion analysis and electrical circuit design.

objectives.description: Understand fundamental physics principles across mechanics, thermodynamics, waves, and electricity.
Apply physics concepts to solve real-world problems, such as calculating energy requirements or motion dynamics.
Conduct experiments to validate physical laws and analyze data using graphical methods.
Promote care for the environment, indigenous knowledge, social values, and ethics through physics applications.
Construct simple models to illustrate physical concepts, such as pendulums or electrical circuits.

topics.description: Derive expression for period of simple pendulum
topics.elaboration: Calculate the period of a simple pendulum using the formula T = 2π√(L/g), with applications in timekeeping devices.

topics.description: Describe scalar and vector products
topics.elaboration: Explain scalar (dot) and vector (cross) products, with examples like work (scalar) and torque (vector) calculations.

topics.description: Understand the meaning and applications of scalar and vector products
topics.elaboration: Apply scalar products to compute work done and vector products for torque in mechanical systems.

topics.description: Relative velocity
topics.elaboration: Analyze motion of objects relative to different reference frames, such as a boat crossing a river.

topics.description: Equation of motion using calculus and graphical methods
topics.elaboration: Derive equations of motion using integration and analyze motion graphs (e.g., velocity vs. time).

topics.description: Define and use force as rate of change of momentum
topics.elaboration: Relate force to momentum change in dynamic systems, such as rocket propulsion.

topics.description: State and prove the principle of conservation of linear momentum
topics.elaboration: Demonstrate conservation of momentum in collisions, such as billiard ball interactions.

topics.description: Define centripetal force
topics.elaboration: Explain the force required for circular motion, with examples like planetary orbits or car turns.

topics.description: Derive the expression for centripetal acceleration and solve related problems
topics.elaboration: Derive a = v²/r and apply it to problems like satellite motion.

topics.description: Conical pendulum
topics.elaboration: Analyze the motion of a conical pendulum and derive its period, used in mechanical systems like governors.

topics.description: Motion in a vertical circle
topics.elaboration: Study forces and energy in vertical circular motion, such as a roller coaster loop.

topics.description: Applications of banking
topics.elaboration: Apply banking angle concepts to design safe road curves for vehicles.

topics.description: Define Young’s modulus, bulk modulus, and Poisson’s ratio
topics.elaboration: Explain elastic moduli and their applications in material science, such as bridge construction.

topics.description: Derive the expression for energy stored in a stretched wire
topics.elaboration: Calculate elastic potential energy in deformed materials, like springs in machinery.

topics.description: Solve numerical problems and conceptual questions regarding elasticity
topics.elaboration: Address problems involving stress, strain, and elastic moduli in real-world structures.

topics.description: Linear expansion and its measurement
topics.elaboration: Measure thermal expansion in solids using experimental setups, like railway track gaps.

topics.description: Explain linear, superficial, cubical expansion and define their coefficients
topics.elaboration: Differentiate types of thermal expansion and calculate coefficients for materials.

topics.description: Explain the phenomenon of interference
topics.elaboration: Describe constructive and destructive interference with examples like sound waves or light patterns.

topics.description: Understand the meaning of coherent sources and their significance
topics.elaboration: Explain the role of coherent sources in producing stable interference patterns, as in lasers.

topics.description: Learn the relation between refractive indices and total internal reflection
topics.elaboration: Analyze light behavior at boundaries, calculating critical angles for optical fibers.

topics.description: Describe Meter bridge and understand its use
topics.elaboration: Explain the working principle of a Meter bridge for measuring unknown resistances.

topics.description: Know construction, working, and importance of Potentiometer
topics.elaboration: Describe potentiometer applications in measuring EMF and potential differences in circuits.

topics.description: State Coulomb’s law
topics.elaboration: Apply Coulomb’s law to calculate forces between point charges, as in electrostatic interactions.

topics.description: Use electron volt as a unit of electric potential energy
topics.elaboration: Convert energy values to electron volts for atomic-scale calculations, like electron transitions.

topics.description: Recall and use V = Q/(4πε₀r) for electric potential
topics.elaboration: Calculate electric potential due to point charges, applicable in capacitor design.

practical_activities.description: Verification of Ohm’s law and determination of resistance of a thin-film resistor by graphical method
practical_activities.elaboration: Plot voltage vs. current to confirm linearity and calculate resistance, used in circuit analysis.

practical_activities.description: Determination of the coefficient of viscosity of a liquid by Stoke’s method
practical_activities.elaboration: Graphically analyze terminal velocity to compute viscosity, applicable in fluid dynamics.

practical_activities.description: Study the variation of image distance with respect to object distance
practical_activities.elaboration: Use lens formula to analyze image formation in optical systems, like camera lenses.

practical_activities.description: Compare rise of water in capillaries of different diameters dipped in water
practical_activities.elaboration: Measure capillary rise to study surface tension, relevant to plant water transport.

practical_activities.description: Study the status of hydroelectricity in Nepal
practical_activities.elaboration: Analyze data on hydroelectric power generation and its physics principles, like energy conversion.

practical_activities.description: Study the application of physics laws in a chosen context
practical_activities.elaboration: Apply physics principles to a real-world scenario, e.g., energy conservation in mechanical systems.

components.elaboration: Assess engagement in discussions and group activities, fostering collaborative learning.
Evaluate theoretical understanding through periodic written tests.
Assess hands-on experiments and project reports, emphasizing practical skills.

external.description: Based on specification chart by Curriculum Development Centre, assessing knowledge, skills, and application through written exams.

methods: Group discussions (satellite learning group, peer group, small and large group)

assessment_approach.description: Explain how to measure a variable in an experiment
assessment_approach.elaboration: Assess ability to describe experimental measurement techniques, e.g., using a vernier caliper.

assessment_approach.description: Explain relationships between variables in an experiment
assessment_approach.elaboration: Evaluate understanding of variable interactions, like force vs. acceleration.

assessment_approach.description: Value of constants or prediction with justification
assessment_approach.elaboration: Assess ability to derive constants or predict outcomes, e.g., gravitational constant.

assessment_approach.description: Handling of errors and precautions in experiments
assessment_approach.elaboration: Evaluate error analysis and experimental precautions.
Assess verbal explanation of experimental procedures and results.

measurement_tools.use: Measure lengths and diameters accurately, e.g., in mechanics experiments.
Measure curvature of surfaces, like lenses in optics.
Measure small dimensions with high precision, e.g., wire thickness.
Measure time intervals in experiments, like pendulum periods.
